Draft version January 6, 2021
Typeset using LATEX default style in AASTeX62
Helioseismic Signatures of One- and Two-Cell Meridional Circulation
Andrey M. Stejko,1 Alexander G. Kosovichev,1 and Valery V. Pipin2
1New Jersey Institute of Technology
323 Dr Martin Luther King Jr Blvd.

Newark, NJ 07012, USA
2Institute of Solar-Terrestrial Physics
Russian Academy of Sciences
Irkutsk, 664033, Russia
(Received –; Revised –; Accepted –)
Submitted to ApJ
ABSTRACT
Using a 3D global solver of the linearized Euler equations, we model acoustic oscillations over back-
ground velocity flow fields of single-cell meridional circulation with deep and shallow return flows as
well as a double-cell meridional circulation profile. The velocities are generated using a mean-field
hydrodynamic and dynamo model – moving through the regimes with minimal parameter changes;
counter-rotation near the base of the tachocline is induced by sign inversion of the non-diffusive action
of turbulent Reynolds stresses (Λ-effect) due to the radial inhomogeneity of the Coriolis number. By
mimicking the stochastic excitation of resonant modes in the convective interior, we simulate real-
ization noise present in solar observations. Using deep-focusing to analyze differences in travel-time
signatures between the three regimes, as well as comparing to solar observations, we show that current
helioseismology techniques may offer important insights about the location of the return flow, how-
ever, that it may not be possible to definitively distinguish between profiles of single-cell or double-cell
meridional circulation.
Keywords: Helioseismology, Computational Methods, Solar Meridional Circulation
1. INTRODUCTION

Meridional mass flows are characterized by large circulation structures, redistributing angular momentum and mag-
netic flux (Hathaway et al. 2003) throughout the convective interior of the Sun. Doppler measurements have been used
to study the surface expressions of these circulation cells in detail (Duvall 1979; Hathaway 1996; Ulrich 2010), showing
strong poleward flows (20 m s−1) in each hemisphere. The Michelson Doppler Imager (MDI) (Scherrer et al. 1995)
of the Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SOHO) (Domingo et al. 1995), its successor – the Helioseismic Magnetic
Imager (HMI) (Scherrer et al. 2012) aboard the Solar Data Observatory (SDO) spacecraft (Pesnell et al. 2012), as well
as the Global Oscillation Network Group (GONG) (Harvey et al. 1996) have been instrumental in providing the long
term observational data needed to analyze these structures.
Applying techniques in local helioseismology to these observations allows us to probe below the solar surface
(Christensen-Dalsgaard 2002; Gizon & Birch 2005); cross-correlating measurements of surface oscillations provides
insight into the structure of flows that advect acoustic rays resonating throughout the convective interior. While
measurements in subsurface layers (> 0.96R�) have remained relatively consistent (e.g. Giles et al. 1997; Zhao &
Kosovichev 2004), complications arise when attempting to probe deeper into the solar interior. The return flow of the

circulation cell has historically been theorized to sit near the tachocline (∼ 0.72 R�), with a velocity weaker than that
of the surface flow by an order of magnitude (∼ 2 m s−1) (Giles 1999) – the minimal impact of these flows, along with
Corresponding author: Andrey Stejko
ams226@njit.edu
mailto: ams226@njit.edu
2 Stejko et al.
systematic errors that are not yet fully understood (Rajaguru & Antia 2020), lead to significant difficulties in clearly
resolving deep meridional circulation structures.
The manifestation of these difficulties can be seen in the variability of inferred meridional velocity profiles, with

more recent estimates of much shallower return flow depths (from ∼ 40 to ∼ 70 Mm; Mitra-Kraev & Thompson
(2007); Hathaway (2012) respectively). The nature of the single-cell model has also been put into question with a
helioseismic analysis of HMI data (Zhao et al. 2013; Chen 2019) inferring a two-cell structure – a result whose viability
has been validated by numerical, convectively driven, MHD/HD simulations (Brun & Toomre 2002; Miesch et al. 2006;
Guerrero et al. 2013; Matilsky et al. 2019). Recent analysis of MDI and GONG data, however, continues to insist
on the single-cell model (Gizon et al. 2020) – typically employed by mean-field simulations of the Sun (Rempel 2005;
Hotta & Yokoyama 2011; Küker et al. 2011; Kitchatinov 2013) and other late-type stars (Kitchatinov & Olemskoy
The transition between single- and double-cell circulation structures has been explored in conjunction with anti-Solar
and Solar profiles of differential rotation in the convectively driven hydrodynamic models of Guerrero et al. (2013);
Gastine et al. (2014); Käpylä et al. (2014); Featherstone & Miesch (2015). These simulations highlight the impact
of angular momentum transport by non-diffusive turbulent Reynolds stresses via gyroscopic pumping (the Λ-effect,
Ruediger (1989); Kichatinov & Rudiger (1993)). Mean-field modeling has shown that altering this parameter (Λ)
(Bekki & Yokoyama 2017) can induce the formation of counter-rotation cells in the lower convection zone, with Pipin
& Kosovichev (2018) demonstrating that radial variations of the Coriolis number near the tachocline can be a potential
physical basis for inducing a sign inversion in Λ.
In this paper, we employ the GALE (Global Acoustic Linearized Euler) code (Stejko et al. 2021), simulating the
propagation of acoustic waves through shallow and deep single-cell, as well as double-cell regimes of meridional back-
ground flows – generated by the mean-field non-linear hydrodynamic and dynamo models of Pipin & Kosovichev (2018,
2019). These models allow us to examine the helioseismic signatures generated by each regime, as well as offering a
baseline for the low-end of variance in travel-time measurements that characterize shallow single-cell and double-cell
meridional circulation – generated by minimal parameter changes near the base of the tachocline. Previous conclu-
sions on the nature of meridional circulation circulation structure have been inferred with the aid of ad-hoc models
(Zhao et al. 2013; Chen 2019; Hartlep et al. 2013; Gizon et al. 2020); we hope that a forward-modeling approach to
examining velocity profiles generated by mean-field models will lend important insights into observations made with
current helioseismology techniques.

This paper is organized as follows. In §2 we briefly describe the formulation of the GALE code. In §3 we outline
the deep focusing method used to measure travel-time differences of acoustic rays propagating throughout the solar

interior, and in §4, we present the results of these measurements on three models (K1, M1 & M2) of meridional
circulation. In §5 we offer an analysis and discussion of these results.
2. MODEL BACKGROUND
The GALE (Global Acoustic Linearized Euler) algorithm (Stejko et al. 2021) solves the conservation form of the

linearized compressible Euler equations on a fully global 3-dimensional grid: 0 ≤ φ ≤ 2π, 0 < θ < π, 0 < r ≤ R�. The
linear approximation is solved for perturbations of the potential flow field (denoted by a prime), over background field
terms (denoted by a tilde) derived from the standard solar model S (Christensen-Dalsgaard et al. 1996).

Υ is defined as the divergence of the momentum field m (Υ = ∇·m = ∇·ρu), computing perturbations in the potential
flow field and omitting solenoidal terms in our governing equations. Perturbations are initiated by a randomized
source function (S), mimicking the stochastic excitation of acoustic modes in the convective interior (Woodard 1984).
Governing Eqns. (1) - (3) are computed in the pseudo-spectral regime through spherical harmonic decomposition

(f =
∑
lm aYlm) of field terms (Υ, ρ, p, u) using the Libsharp spherical harmonic library (Reinecke & Seljebotn 2013).
Meridional Circulation 3
The current form of our governing equations (Eqns. 1 - 3) are solved in a vector spherical harmonic (VSH) basis, while

the material derivative is solved in its Cauchy conservation form (∇ : (m′ũ + ρ̃ũu′)) using a symmetric tensor spherical
harmonic (TSH) basis. This formulation allows for the use of recursion relations to compute derivatives tangent to
the surface of the sphere (∂/∂θ, ∂/∂φ), resulting in the 1D radial relations we solve in our time-discretization scheme.
The conservation of energy (Eq. 3) is computed as a relationship between pressure and the compressible momentum
field in the adiabatic approximation (Christensen-Dalsgaard 2014), where heat transfer is neglected. Convective action
in the background model is treated separately by isolating the Brunt-Väisälä frequency (N2). In order to avoid
growing convective instabilities, we set the slightly negative values of the Brunt-Väisälä frequency in the convection
zone (N2 < 0) to zero – obviating the need to modify background profiles of density, pressure and the adiabatic
ratio (Γ1), see Hanasoge et al. (2006); Parchevsky & Kosovichev (2007); Papini et al. (2014). A full description and
validation of the model’s algorithm can be found Stejko et al. (2021).
3. METHOD
The spatial resolution of the model is set by the spherical harmonic degree l = 200. This value corresponds to an
azimuthal resolution of Nφ = 600 and a latitudinal resolution of Nθ = 450, chosen to avoid aliasing errors during
sampling. This resolution allows for the detection of signals throughout the convection zone to an upper limit of

∼ 0.96R�. The temporal cadence of the model is 3 seconds with data being saved at 1 minute intervals for a total
of 67 hours (4000 minutes) – a time-scale too short to effectively resolve signals in the convection zone (Braun &
Birch 2008). We can improve the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) by increasing the background velocities in our model
by a factor of 36 (see Hartlep et al. (2013)), mimicking the SNR we would expect in approximately a decade of solar
observations – within the operational time-frame of HMI.
Acoustic oscillations traveling through the solar interior are advected by regimes of mean mass flows in the convection
zone. Measuring perturbations on the solar surface allows for the application of local helioseismology techniques (see
Gizon & Birch (2005)) in order to infer the structure of these internal flow velocities. We employ the technique of
deep focusing (Charbonneau 2005; Zhao et al. 2009), in which radial velocity perturbtaions at two points on the
model surface, separated by some angular distance (∆), are cross-correlated. The resulting correlation signal forms
the charectristic profile of a Gabor wavelet (Kosovichev & Duvall 1997; Giles 1999; Nigam et al. 2007), which can be
described by the function:

l(l + 1) is the horizontal phase velocity and u = ∂ω/∂kh is the horizontal group velocity. The function is
summed over a narrow range of phase velocities δv. We fit this function (Eq. 4) to our cross-correlated signal using
the iterative Levenberg-Marquardt method, providing an estimate of the time-lag from the group and phase velocities.
In order to measure the impact of meridional flow fields on acoustic rays, we subtract the time-lag (τ) of southward
traveling waves from their northward traveling counterparts (δτNS). The ray-path approximation (Giles 1999) then
offers a basis for inferring the magnitude of the velocity field in the direction of the travelling acoustic ray (assuming
the path of the ray Γ0 remains unperturbed).

u · n
c2
Although this functions omits non-linear effects of large flow velocities, it serves as a good approximation of travel-time
differences – seen by computed travel-time comparisons in Fig. 4.
This method is applied to the surface mesh-grid of our model, sampled at approximately 300 km above the photo-
sphere (1.0004R�). Each pixel (Nθ x Nφ = 450 x 600) is treated as a center point around which cubic hermite splines
are used to remap a 60◦ x 60◦ patch into azimuthal equidistant coordinates (Postel’s proejection) at a resolution of
approximately 0.6◦ per pixel. Great circle distances (∆) are selected at every interval (1.2◦) from 0◦ to 60◦, for
which 30◦ wide sectors in the north and south (2 pixels in radius) are averaged and cross-correlated with each other.
This signal can be enhanced by averaging over every point in the longitude (Nφ = 600) and smoothed by averaging

±3◦ (±5 pix) in the latitude. We can further smooth our data by averaging the diameter of each great circle over
±2.4◦, where travel time offsets are interpolated to an estimated time-lag using the ray-path approximation (Thank
4 Stejko et al.
you to Dr. Ruizhu Chen for suggesting this smoothing technique). The application of this method allows for the
measurement of acoustic travel times and inferences of meridional velocities throughout the convection zone – from
the convective-radiative interface at the tachocline (0.70R�) to near the solar surface (0.96R�). An illustration of the
remapping and pixel selection technique, along with corresponding acoustic ray-paths through the model interior can
be seen in Fig. 1.

Figure 1. An illustration of the deep-focusing method. Left) A 60◦ x 60◦ patch is remapped into azimuthal equidistant
coordinates, pixels are selected in 30◦ wide northern and southern sectors (2 pixels in radius). Right) The acoustic ray-paths
associated with the selected travel distances.
4. MERIDIONAL PROFILES

We apply the deep focusing method (§3) to three profiles of meridional circulation generated by non-linear mean-
field hydrodynamic and dynamo models. The first is a single-cell meridional circulation model with a deep return flow
situated near the base of the tachocline – based on the mean-field model of Kichatinov (2004) and described as model
M2 in Pipin & Kosovichev (2018); in this paper we will refer to this model as K1 in order to avoid confusion. The
next two are a shallow single-cell, with return flow at approximately 0.80R�, and a double-cell meridional circulation
profile referred to as M1 and M2 respectively in Pipin & Kosovichev (2019). These meridional velocities are used as
the background terms (ũr,ũθ) in our governing equations (1-3). The latitudinal velocities (ũθ) for the models (M1 &
M2) are shown in Fig. 2, with streamlines representing the circulation profile.
We characterize internal meridional flow profiles by plotting N-S travel-time differences (δτNS) as a function of their
are compared to theoretical travel-time differences (dashed lines) computed using the ray-path approximation (Eq. 5).
Randomized functions are used to generate the oscillatory signal in our source (S, Eq. 2, see Stejko et al. (2021) for
a detailed description) resulting in unique profiles of realization noise – of which three different profiles are shown for
models K1, M1 and M2 (Fig. 3). To measure the bounds of our noise, we use 100 unique source functions on a model
with no background flows; the noise can then be characterized as the standard deviation (σNS) of the measured signal
from zero:

N∑
i=1
Error-bars in Fig. 3 show one standard deviation of the noise. We can improve the SNR in our measurements
significantly – especially at larger travel distances, by applying a phase-velocity filter to our data prior to deep focusing.
The filter is defined as a Gaussian function in phase-velocity space (Nigam et al. 2007) with a width of σ = 0.05v,
where v is the phase speed (ω/l(l + 1)). The resulting travel-time differences can be seen at the bottom of Fig. 3.
Meridional Circulation 5

Figure 2. Latitudinal velocities (ũθ), generated by the mean-field models of Pipin & Kosovichev (2018) (K1 – referred to as
M2 in their paper) and Pipin & Kosovichev (2019) (M1 and M2). a) Single-cell meridional circulation with a deep return flow
near the base of the tachocline. b) Single-cell meridional circulation with a shallow return flow at ∼ 0.80R�. c) Double-cell
meridional circulation. Solid and dashed contours represent counterclockwise and clockwise rotation respectively.

◦N − 50◦N, 10◦N − 30◦N, 10◦S − 10◦N, 10◦S − 30◦S,
30◦S − 50◦S. Dashed lines are theoretical times computed using the ray-path approximation (Eq. 5). Error bars show the
standard deviation of the measured realization noise (σNS , Eq. 6).
Comparing the signals from the three models, we see a noticeable variation in the travel-time differences of the
deep single-cell (K1) profile – showing a much less rapid decrease with travel distance, resulting in a gap wider than
one standard deviation of the noise throughout a large part of the convective interior. The shallow single-cell and
double-cell regimes (M1 and M2 respectively) however, fall within one standard deviation of the range of realization
noise, even with the significant increase in the SNR through the application of a phase-velocity filter. These results
6 Stejko et al.
have positive implications for distinguishing between deep and shallow single-cell meridional circulation, however
the differences between shallow single- and double-cell profiles are much more subtle; using current helioseismology

techniques, within the time-frame of HMI measurements (∼ 10 years), any definitive statements on whether meridional
circulation has one or two cells may be difficult to make.
In order to highlight systematic errors present in our model, as well as compare our measurements to ray-path
theory, we subtract noise profiles from our measurements of travel-time differences in models K1, M1 and M2, for the
phase-speed filtered data-set (Fig. 4) – revealing a close and consistent agreement with the travel-time differences
computed using the ray-path approximation.

Figure 4. The N-S travel-time differences (δτNS) as a function of travel distance (∆) for models K1 (a), M1 (b) and M2
(c) under the application of Gaussian phase-speed filter (σ = 0.05vp) with profiles of noise subtracted, showing 5 latitudinal
averages spanning 30◦N − 50◦N, 10◦N − 30◦N, 10◦S − 10◦N, 10◦S − 30◦S, 30◦S − 50◦S. Dashed lines are theoretical times
computed using the ray-path approximation (Eq. 5).
We further compare our models to the publicly available data from the analysis of Gizon et al. (2020) (Fig. 5),
scaling the travel-time differences computed using the ray-path approximation in our models (K1, M1 & M2), to their
travel-time measurements using MDI/GONG observations for Solar Cycle 24 (2008-2019). It is apparent that the
level of noise is too large to draw significant conclusions distinguishing single- and double-cell regimes of of meridional
circulation (M1 & M2), however the measurements do seem to be more consistent with shallower return flow (M1) as
opposed to a deeper one (K1).

Figure 5. The N-S travel-time differences (δτNS) as a function of travel distance (∆) for MDI/GONG data published by
Gizon et al. (2020). Latitude ranges in both hemispheres (10◦N − 30◦N, 10◦S − 30◦S) are averaged in order to reduce noise
and are compared to dashed lines representing latitudinal averages for models K1, M1 and M2 as measured using the ray-path
approximation (Eq. 5). Error-bars are computed as the standard deviation (σ, Eq. 6) of the travel-time differences in the
10◦N − 10◦S latitude range from zero.
Meridional Circulation 7
5. DISCUSSION
The question on the nature of meridional circulation remains an outstanding one. Large variations in inferences
have been made using similar local helioseismology techniques – from a double-cell meridional circulation profile seen
in HMI observations (Zhao et al. 2013; Chen 2019) to recent re-assertions of a single cell profile from MDI/GONG
data (Gizon et al. 2020). The feasibility of the two regimes has been explored in recent years, with convectively driven
MHD and HD models reproducing the necessary environment for both.
The actual differences may lie somewhere in between the large variations inferred in the two models. To that end
we test the feasibly of discerning between deep and shallow single-cell as well as double-cell profiles of meridional
circulation, generated by the same mean-field model, operating with minimal parameter changes (K1 in Pipin &
Kosovichev (2018) – referred to as M2 in their paper; M1 & M2 in Pipin & Kosovichev (2019)). Using the GALE code
(Stejko et al. 2021) to simulate the stochastic excitation of acoustic modes throughout the convective interior, we apply
the deep focusing method to measure the resulting travel-time differences. Analyzing the profiles of realization noise
generated by the model shows that the maximal differences between a shallow single-cell and double-cell regime fall well
within one standard deviation of error for both phase-speed filtered and unfiltered deep-focusing measurements. The
deep single-cell profile (K1), however, shows enough differences to be distinguishable from the two other models (M1
& M2). Comparing the resulting profiles to a decade of solar observations shows that while any definitive statements
on the prevalence of either a single- or double-cell regime should be taken with a grain of salt, meaningful conclusions
on the nature of the return flow are within the reach of current techniques in helioseismology.
AMS would like to thank the heliophysics modeling and simulation team at NASA Ames Research Center for help
and guidance. VVP would like to thank the FR project II.16.3 of ISTP SB RAS for their support. This work is
supported by the NASA grants: 80NSSC19K0630, 80NSSC19K1436, NNX14AB7CG and NNX17AE76A.
